itemDescription: British World War I flying ace

wikipedia_page.main: Captain John William Pinder DFC (14 February 1898 – 16 August 1920) was a British First World War flying ace, who flew for the Royal Navy Air Service, and later the Royal Air Force.

response: He was posted to No. 13 (Naval) Squadron to fly the Sopwith Camel single seat fighter. He destroyed an enemy two-seater on 5 December 1917, aided by fellow aces John Pinder, George Chisholm MacKay, and John Paynter. On 29 January 1918, aided by MacKay, Paynter, John Edmund Greene, and Leonard Slatter, he destroyed a seaplane. On 12 March 1918, Cooper shared another victory with Greene, MacKay, and another pilot. On 1 April, Cooper flamed a German two-seater seaplane at Zeebrugge, killing M. R. Behrendt and D. R. Hauptvogel. On 3 June, in the King's Birthday Honours he was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross, and on 3 July he was appointed a flight commander with the temporary rank of captain. On 7 July, he, Charles Sims, and four other pilots drove down an Albatros D.V. On 30 July 1918, he drove down another D.V at Bruges. That made his tally four enemy aircraft destroyed, three of which were shared wins, and two driven down out of control, one of which was shared.
|1 || 5 December 1917@ 1505 || Sopwith Camel(B6407) || C || Destroyed ||  north-west of Wenduine || Shared with Flight Sub-Lieutenants John Pinder, George MacKay & John Paynter.
|3 || 25 July 1917@ 1730 || Sopwith Camel(B3820) || C || Out of control || Off Westende || Shared with Flight Sub-Lieutenants John Pinder, Oliver Redgate, Harold Mott, & Snell.
John Pinder or Jack Pinder may refer to:
*John Pinder (RAF officer) (1898–1920), British World War I flying ace
*John Pinder (comedy producer) (1945–2015), Australian comedy producer and festival director
